text: I keep telling my wallet to lose weight, but it just keeps getting lighter.
author: Paul

text: I tried cooking today. Let’s just say the smoke detector had a great workout.
author: Paul

text: My alarm clock and I are in a toxic relationship. It rings, I ignore, we fight daily.
author: Paul

text: They say money can’t buy happiness, but it definitely pays the internet bill.
author: Paul

text: I went for a run today… to the fridge and back. Fitness achieved.
author: Paul

text: If procrastination was an Olympic sport, I’d compete… tomorrow.
author: Paul

text: I tried to clean my room. Now I can’t find anything. Mission failed successfully.
author: Paul

text: Some people jog to clear their mind. I sleep for the same result.
author: Paul

text: I’m not lazy, I’m just saving my energy for something important. Still waiting for that important thing.
author: Paul

text: My mirror and I have an agreement: it doesn’t judge me, and I don’t clean it.
author: Paul

text: Every time I diet, my fridge gets lonely and calls me back.
author: Paul

text: The Wi-Fi went off for five minutes, and suddenly my family started talking to me. Weird.
author: Paul

text: I believe in exercise. That’s why I walk away from problems.
author: Paul

text: I don’t snore. I just dream like I’m a motorbike.
author: Paul

text: My brain has too many tabs open, and none of them are responding.
author: Paul

text: They say you are what you eat. I must be bread and noodles by now.
author: Paul

text: I’m not short-tempered, I just have a fast reaction time to nonsense.
author: Paul

text: I don’t need a hair stylist. My pillow gives me a new look every morning.
author: Paul

text: My math teacher said I’d never use algebra in real life. Joke’s on me, I still don’t.
author: Paul

text: The best workout is running… out of excuses.
author: Paul

text: I tried meditating, but I fell asleep and woke up spiritually confused.
author: Paul

text: I love long walks… especially when they’re taken by people who annoy me.
author: Paul

text: Some people say the glass is half full, others say half empty. I say, who drank my juice?
author: Paul

text: The early bird might get the worm, but the second mouse gets the cheese.
author: Paul

text: I finally got my steps in today—straight from the bed to the couch.
author: Paul

text: If laziness was a talent, I’d already have a Netflix documentary.
author: Paul

text: I bought a calendar to get my life together. Now I just stare at my failures in order.
author: Paul

text: Every time I exercise, I remember how much I miss sitting.
author: Paul

text: They say laughter is the best medicine, but I still can’t pay the pharmacy with jokes.
author: Paul

text: My phone battery and my motivation die at the same speed.
author: Paul

text: I cleaned my house yesterday, and today it looks like I was never even home.
author: Paul

text: I joined a fitness class. The warm-up was enough to convince me to go home.
author: Paul

text: They say patience is a virtue. I say it’s a waiting game I always lose.
author: Paul

text: The fridge light is my nightlight. It guides me to happiness at 2 a.m.
author: Paul

text: I thought I wanted a career, but it turns out I just wanted a paycheck.
author: Paul

text: Some call it laziness, I call it selective participation.
author: Paul

text: I don’t trust people who don’t like pizza. What are you hiding?
author: Paul

text: They said dress for the job you want. Now I’m unemployed in pajamas.
author: Paul

text: If my bed had arms, I’d never leave it.
author: Paul

text: I only run when something is chasing me… preferably with teeth.
author: Paul

text: They told me to follow my dreams, so I went back to sleep.
author: Paul

text: The only abs I have are absolutely hidden.
author: Paul

text: I planned to be productive today, but Netflix disagreed.
author: Paul

text: My bed and I are in a committed relationship. We only break up for work.
author: Paul

text: I’m not late, I’m just running on my own unique timeline.
author: Paul

text: I don’t like morning people. Or mornings. Or people.
author: Paul

text: If sleep was a subject, I’d graduate with honors.
author: Paul

text: They told me not to give up. So I didn’t. I just postponed.
author: Paul

text: The best way to avoid mistakes is to never try. Works every time.
author: Paul

text: I don’t need a GPS, I get lost naturally.
author: Paul

text: My cooking is so unique, even the smoke alarm cheers me on.
author: Paul

text: I like my jokes like my Wi-Fi—free and everywhere.
author: Paul

text: Why chase dreams when my bed delivers them daily?
author: Paul

text: I tried adulting once. Worst decision of my life.
author: Paul

text: They said life is what you make it. I must have ordered mine on discount.
author: Paul

text: I’m so good at sleeping, I can do it with my eyes closed.
author: Paul

text: The only crunches I do are with potato chips.
author: Paul

text: I don’t do drama. Unless it’s on Netflix.
author: Paul

text: The floor is just my yoga mat when I drop my snacks.
author: Paul

text: If talking burned calories, I’d be a fitness model.
author: Paul

text: I’m not lazy, I’m just energy efficient.
author: Paul

text: The only marathon I run is on streaming platforms.
author: Paul

text: They say practice makes perfect. That’s why I never practice.
author: Paul

text: I asked my fridge for advice. It told me to chill.
author: Paul

text: The only rock I lift is from my shoe.
author: Paul

text: If my life had a soundtrack, it would be buffering.
author: Paul

text: My talent is losing things I just had in my hand.
author: Paul

text: They said be yourself. Bad idea, people ran away.
author: Paul

text: I set goals. Then I take naps until they expire.
author: Paul

text: If stress burned calories, I’d be invisible by now.
author: Paul

text: I can resist everything except snacks.
author: Paul

text: My memory is so bad I could plan my own surprise party.
author: Paul

text: Why do laundry when you can buy new socks?
author: Paul

text: The only plan I stick to is not having a plan.
author: Paul

text: They said count your blessings. I counted my debts instead.
author: Paul

text: I don’t trip, I just test gravity frequently.
author: Paul

text: My phone autocorrect knows me better than I do.
author: Paul

text: If laziness had a fan club, I’d join online so I don’t have to leave the house.
author: Paul

text: The only time I open my wallet fast is when there’s food involved.
author: Paul

text: My Wi-Fi signal is stronger than my willpower.
author: Paul

text: They told me to follow the rules. I unfollowed.
author: Paul

text: I don’t need therapy, I just need unlimited snacks.
author: Paul

text: My idea of multitasking is eating while watching TV.
author: Paul

text: If sarcasm burned calories, I’d be a skeleton.
author: Paul

text: My mood depends entirely on Wi-Fi speed.
author: Paul

text: The only crunch time I know is snack time.
author: Paul

text: I didn’t oversleep. I was just charging myself longer.
author: Paul

text: Life’s too short to match socks.
author: Paul

text: If yawning was exercise, I’d be ripped.
author: Paul

text: I don’t chase dreams. I let them find me while I nap.
author: Paul

text: The only goal I score is in video games.
author: Paul

text: If laziness was a degree, I’d graduate with distinction.
author: Paul

text: My exercise plan is walking to the kitchen repeatedly.
author: Paul

text: I’m so broke even my jokes can’t afford laughter.
author: Paul

text: The only running I do is out of patience.
author: Paul

text: My biggest talent is making simple things complicated.
author: Paul

text: I can cook minute rice in 59 seconds. That’s talent.
author: Paul

text: The best part of exercise is when it’s over.
author: Paul

text: They said think outside the box. I didn’t even open it.
author: Paul

text: The only crunch I trust is from chips.
author: Paul

text: If laziness was contagious, I’d be patient zero.
author: Paul

text: I set alarms just to ignore them.
author: Paul

text: My idea of balanced diet is holding food in both hands.
author: Paul

text: If common sense was common, I’d be out of jokes.
author: Paul
